It appears we are at the very beginning of a spring COVID wave in Ontario. Wastewater signals from many parts of the province are up.

It is currently unclear how large this wave (or wavelet?) will be, but it would not be surprising to see a bump in hospitalizations soon. https://t.co/75VaCYO1Za

Waiting for Evusheld approval in Canada (shortly?). 

There are immunocompromised individuals at greater risk for severe COVID. 

We could put this to very good use. https://t.co/KJCfTeZ1F2

This is a good thread outlining 2 recent studies demonstrating how masking in schools can reduce COVID transmission.

Study 1: https://t.co/a4w2UB8MLe
Study 2: https://t.co/P8w81fvXad

While no study (or mask) is perfect, these help illustrate the role of masking in this setting. https://t.co/AnREYDvGLs https://t.co/KoXkZO9XIS

Great thread discussing how, due to growing population level immunity via vaccination, recovery from infection (or both), COVID now has a lower mortality risk VS the flu in England.

Also important:
*COVID (& flu) cause significant morbidity/mortality
*COVID is not the flu https://t.co/scg0ERUxTp

Masks are a helpful (but imperfect) tool to create safer indoor environments, especially during a respiratory virus pandemic.

Our Omicron wave is subsiding but is not over.

I think it is reasonable to keep masks on for now & re-evaluate weekly.

3/ Last point: There are many smart locations to administer COVID therapeutics (eg. primary care, urgent care, home-based, etc). 

The key is equitable, timely and safe access to evidence-based treatments. Pharmacies (and pharmacists) can play a major role.

Test-to-Treat for COVID at pharmacies is a very smart idea.

1. Free access to testing & COVID therapeutics
2. Pharmacists are experts in drug-interactions (an issue with some therapeutics)
3. Many pharmacies are well equipped for testing
4. Lower barriers to receive TIMELY care https://t.co/5UEuYgMbh9
